mainTopic.title: Movement Disorder Drugs
mainTopic.content_info: The lecture handouts come with a lot of detailed information that is sufficient to cover the whole topic

subTopics.title: Overview of movement disorders and Parkinson's disease

quizzes.question: What are the cardinal signs of Parkinson's disease?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Rest tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, impairment of postural reflexes
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Photophobia, weight gain, skin rash, insomnia
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Muscle spasms, shortness of breath, anxiety, depression

quizzes.question: What neurologic disorder affects over 3% of individuals over the age of 65?
What is a common etiological factor implicated in Parkinson's disease?
What enzyme is responsible for the synthesis of dopamine from tyrosine?
What two main enzymes are involved in the catabolism of dopamine?
Which dopamine receptor types are primarily extrastriatal?
quizzes.goodAnswer: d5 (D type) and d3, d4 (D type)

quizzes.question: What is the precursor of dopamine that is used in treatment of Parkinson's disease?
Why is levodopa typically administered with carbidopa?
quizzes.goodAnswer: To inhibit peripheral decarboxylase and prevent breakdown of levodopa before crossing the blood-brain barrier
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: To enhance its potency and stability in the liver
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: To act as a stabilizer for plasma membranes
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: To facilitate quicker absorption in the GI tract
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: To inhibit liver enzymes mediating drug metabolism

quizzes.question: Which COMT inhibitor can cross the blood-brain barrier and is used to manage Parkinson's?
What class of drugs are Pramipexole and Ropinerole?
What are dopamine receptor antagonists primarily used to treat?
Which side effect is associated with long-term use of dopamine receptor antagonists?
Which atypical antipsychotic has specific action at the d4 receptor and can cause neutropenia?
